thread.title: ‘Every aspect of my body had goosebumps’
thread.title_full: ‘Every aspect of my body had goosebumps’

title: ‘Every aspect of my body had goosebumps’
text:
Pilot revealed plane had ‘catastrophic’ engine failure as tributes flow for passengers news.com.au February 21, 2017 8:19pm 
THE pilot at the controls of a plane that crashed and exploded at a Melbourne shopping centre had 38 years experience and an “impeccable safety record”. 
Max Quartermain, 63, died along with four passengers when the light plane took off from Essendon Airport on Tuesday morning before crashing moments later into the Essendon DFO and bursting into flames. 
Australian Corporate Jets chief executive Bas Nikolovski says Mr Quartermain was “one of the most experienced pilots’”. 
“Every aspect of my body had goosebumps” Mr Nikolovski told AAP. 
“It has smashed me for six, and I am a softie at the best of times.” 
Steve Atto, who had flown with Mr Quartermain, said on Facebook that he was a “diligent pilot” and “we all trusted and enjoyed his company”. 
Mr Quartermain owned Corporate and Leisure Aviation with his wife Cilla, operating the business from their Rye home on Victoria’s Mornington Peninsula. media_camera MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA - FEBRUARY 21: A view from the tarmac at Melbourne's Essendon Airport is seen after a charter plane leaving the airport crashed. Picture: Photo by Michael Dodge/Getty Images. media_camera Footage from the scene that luckily did not kill anyone on the ground. Picture: Twitter 
Neighbours reportedly heard Ms Quartermain saying “he’s gone, he’s gone” on Tuesday morning. An ambulance is also understood called to the house to treat a person with breathing problems. 
The company’s website says they have “over 38 years of charter services experience and an impeccable safety record”. 
The plane carrying four passengers and the pilot crashed into DFO shopping centre shortly after taking off from Essendon Airport before 9am. 
Pilot Max Quartermain reported“catastrophic engine failure” before the crash and there were no fatalities at the shopping centre. 
Passengers include four US tourists including Greg Reynolds De Haven, Russell Munsch and reportedly Glenn Garland. The identity of fourth American is not yet known. 
Nearby workers and witnesses described it as being like an “atomic bomb”. 
“We felt just everything shake and a massive explosion and a fireball go up,” said Ash Mayer, a storeman at The Good Guys. 
“I could feel the heat through the window of the taxi, and then a wheel — it looked like a plane wheel — bounced on the road and hit the front of the taxi as we were driving along,” said a witness known only as Jason.
